page.title: 05TREES IN WEST CAMBRIDGESHIRE
page.content: In recent years there has been a dramatic reduction in the number of elm trees, as a result of Dutch Elm Disease. Fortunately, some of the mature elms have so far survived, but the ash now rivals the elm as the main native species. The ravages of Dutch Elm Disease, coupled with the fact that the farmland in the South was once part of a wartime airfield, give the area a rather bare appearance, in which Stow Longa alone remains as a green oasis. Local residents are making a determined effort to replace dead elms with other species, especially near roads. In particular, the planting of horse chestnuts and sycamores on the outskirts of Stow Longa and along the lane to Little Catworth should, in time, restore the leafy appearance of the countryside.
